comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
The lady behind him also has a bit of a smile, and the one on the left looks to be struggling to express a smirk. I wonder when it became obligatory to force a smile for photographs. I once read that the grim expressions in old portraits were the result of long exposures - it's easier to maintain a neutral expression for a few seconds than a smile.

Anyway, I'm glad the gent at the back is maintaining a bit of decorum with his grim expression.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content:
Funny because we've been talking about wristwatches on another Flickr Commons photo:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/smithsonian/3398583060/]
Miss Fitzgerald's watch doesn't look very different from Miss (Dr?) Crossley's...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] Lovely that Kathleen May Crossley was identified, and by her great niece! Yes, these early watches look very large and "masculine" compared to later 20th century women's styles with teeny faces - on the watches, not on the women ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Like father - like son!  The standing son is like the head cut off his Da whereas the daughter on the right hand of the mother looks the spit of the Ma!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Now that's interesting, wasn't seeing any of the young men as old enough to be fathers! Our NLI description says "Mrs Fitzgerald. Otteran Place, group children", and there are a couple of versions with that description and different poses. I was trying to work out who was old enough to be the mother and thought it might be the middle one, but still wasn't happy. However, have gone back to our catalogue, and it looks as if all of this group are Mrs Fitzgerald's children only, but Mrs Fitzgerald herself does appear in another photo with all 6 of her children. My apologies for any confusion. Altering the description now...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 16489083@N05
comment._content:
I think the grin down front was because of the little stool he 
was having to remain seated on through out the sitting...
Maybe his sister whacked him with whatever she has in
her hand... luv this old family portrait... thanks for sharing!!!!
comment.authorname: maorlando God kept us 2012 leaning on Him 2013

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 55597723@N02
comment._content: Nicely Taken. Nice expressions. A very lovely Family.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I see what you mean NLI about the apparent ages of the group.  I suppose I jumped to that conclusion because of the relatively worn state of the jacket, the dour expression and the watch chain.  It gives him a very settled look like a father might with a lively bunch like that to care for.  I guess Maorlando has it right about the hilarity at the front of the shot.  I suspect that the corner of the book in the young lady's hands is poking into the back of the youngest member of the family?

comment.author: 32149975@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03]: Great photo! I also love the expression on the young fella at the front, he's a right cheeky looking divil! :) Happy New Year and I'm looking forward to more gems in 2012!

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/39191857@N05]: I reckon the mother is a widow (otherwise why wouldn't the dad be in the photo?) so I suppose the older boy is taking on the "man of the house" role, hence the more serious expression!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] He's definitely taking the whole thing more seriously than the others! I wonder if he gave out to them afterwards...

comment._content: Nice  Portrait Shots those days .... Greetings from Canada :)

comment.author: 81045058@N03
comment._content: The cheeky chappy was my grandfather Jack Fitzgerald. The other 5 are his older half brothers and sisters

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81045058@N03] Thank you Blaithin for letting us know the connection.  Congratulations Carol, the mighty NLI has struck gold once again by making contact with the descendants of one of the families in the photographs.  Fantastic!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/81045058@N03] Thanks a million! Lovely to have a name for this mischievous boy. If you have any other information you'd like to contribute on the family, please do! It's always great to find out more about the people in our pictures... :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
